name: Erik Trogden
title: Partner/Owner
company: Casago San Diego / North County San Diego

flow.context: Erik Trogden is one of three partner/owners at Casago San Diego / North County San Diego — a Casago franchise managing high-end coastal vacation rentals across Oceanside, Carlsbad, Encinitas, Del Mar, and La Jolla. They just absorbed 150+ homes from Vacasa in August 2025, which means they're onboarding a massive batch of properties with new cleaners who don't know the units yet — massive QA strain. They run Streamline PMS with Property Care X for field ops and publicly promise homeowners 75-point cleaning checklists and monthly 100-point inspections, which gets exponentially harder to honor at this new scale. Erik was quoted in the 2023 franchise launch about growth and responsible operations, suggesting he's the systems-minded partner among the three (Dave Carter and Bert King are the other two). Sam's angle: SoCal native who grew up in LA and spends time in North County — geographic proximity is the strongest natural connection, plus shared entrepreneurial background.

opener.label: OPENER
opener.say: Hey Erik — I work with a few other vacation rental operators down in North County, actually grew up in LA and spend a bunch of time in Carlsbad. It's Sam Parks with RapidEye. Have you heard my name tossed around?
opener.note: Feet up on the desk energy. Say it like you're calling someone a mutual friend told you about. Don't rush the last line — let it hang and wait for a response.

heard_yes.label: THEY'VE HEARD OF YOU
heard_yes.say: Oh nice — well normally we'd be working with someone like you guys. What did you hear?
heard_yes.note: Rare but great. Let them talk. Whatever they say, bridge to discovery. Don't correct or over-explain anything they got wrong.

branches.label: Describes what they heard / asks a question

heard_no.label: HAVEN'T HEARD — TRANSITION
heard_no.say: Ha — I guess I'm not as popular as I thought. Well the reason for my call is actually pretty specific to you guys —
heard_no.note: Smile through the self-deprecating line. It disarms them. Don't pause here — go straight into the pain trigger. This is one continuous thought.

bad_timing.label: BAD TIMING
bad_timing.say: Totally hear you — would it be a terrible idea if I tried you again later this week? I think it'd be worth a couple minutes.
bad_timing.note: Don't push. Your only goal is a specific callback time. If they say 'just call whenever,' pin it down: 'Morning or afternoon work better?'

reschedule_callback.label: CALLBACK LOCKED
reschedule_callback.say: Perfect — I'll try you then. Appreciate it, Erik. Talk soon.
reschedule_callback.note: Write down the exact day and time immediately. Set a calendar reminder. When you call back, open with: 'Hey Erik, it's Sam Parks — you told me to try you back today.'

permission_fallback.label: PERMISSION ASK
permission_fallback.say: Yeah totally — I mean, it is a cold call. Can I get 30 seconds to tell you why I reached out, and you can totally hang up on me if it's not relevant?
permission_fallback.note: This resets the frame. You're acknowledging the interruption honestly and handing them control. Most people will give you the 30 seconds.

permission_rejected.label: PERMISSION REJECTED
permission_rejected.say: Shoot, totally my bad. Just so nobody from my team bugs you again — is it that I caught you at a horrible time, or is it that you already know what we do and this just isn't interesting?
permission_rejected.note: You're splitting the objection to figure out if it's timing or substance. Most people will clarify, and that clarification reopens the door.

branches.label: Not interested in what you do

permission_split.label: SPLIT THE REJECTION
permission_split.say: Totally fair. Is it that you guys have inspections and turnover QA fully dialed in, or more that you just hate getting cold calls — because honestly, I get it.
permission_split.note: You're giving them a low-stakes out ('I just hate cold calls') that most people won't actually take. If they engage on the substance — 'we have it dialed in' — you're back in the conversation.

branches.label: They engage on substance / 'we handle it'
Just hates cold calls / wants off

pain_trigger.label: PAIN TRIGGER — VACASA TRANSITION
pain_trigger.say: So I was actually talking to another manager who went through something pretty similar to what you guys just went through — took on a big batch of homes from another operator. And what they said was the hardest part wasn't the bookings or even the owner relationships. It was the turnovers. Suddenly you've got over a hundred new units, cleaners who are still learning the properties, different standards from the previous manager, and this avalanche of turnover photos coming in every day that nobody has time to really look through. Stuff starts slipping — a cracked tile, a missing set of towels, a stain on a couch nobody flagged — and you don't catch it until an owner does. Or worse, the next guest does. And those are exactly the homes where you're trying to earn trust from scratch.
pain_trigger.note: PAUSE after this. Do NOT rush to the solution. Let the silence sit for at least 3-4 seconds. You just described their exact situation — give them room to react. If they're quiet too long, a soft 'does that resonate at all?' works.

branches.label: We're handling it / 'we have a process for that'
Not interested / 'that's not really our issue'

warm_response.label: THEY'RE WARM — STOP PITCHING, START ASKING
warm_response.say: Yeah, that's exactly what we keep hearing. So I'm curious — with the Vacasa homes coming on board, what's the inspection process actually looking like right now? Are your cleaners documenting everything through Property Care, or is it more of a mixed bag still?
warm_response.note: You just named their actual field ops tool. This shows you did your homework and positions you as someone who lives in their world. Let them talk. Take notes on everything they say — it's gold for the demo.

branches.label: Describes their process / opens up about it
Talks about the Vacasa transition challenges specifically

discovery_inspection_process.label: DISCOVERY — INSPECTION WORKFLOW
discovery_inspection_process.say: Got it. And when those turnover photos come in — who's actually reviewing them? Is that you or one of your partners, or do you have someone on the team going through them before the next guest checks in?
discovery_inspection_process.note: You're trying to find the bottleneck. Three co-owners managing 150+ homes means either someone is reviewing photos manually, or nobody really is. Both answers are good for you.

branches.label: Mentions Dave or Bert handle that side

discovery_vacasa_transition.label: DISCOVERY — VACASA TRANSITION PAIN
discovery_vacasa_transition.say: That makes sense. When you're standardizing a hundred and fifty homes that were run by someone else — are you finding the property condition baselines are all over the place? Like, did you have to basically re-inspect everything to figure out what shape these units were actually in?
discovery_vacasa_transition.note: This is the deepest pain point. Former Vacasa properties almost certainly came with inconsistent documentation. If they confirm this, RapidEye's change detection and baseline comparison is the perfect solve. Let them vent.

branches.label: Asks where you're going with this

solution_drop.label: ONE-SENTENCE SOLUTION
solution_drop.say: So here's why I called — we built an AI that plugs into your existing workflow, into Streamline and Property Care, and it automatically analyzes every turnover photo your cleaners are already taking. It flags damage, missing items, staging issues — stuff that would normally take someone twenty minutes per unit to catch, it does in seconds. No workflow change on the cleaner's end at all.
solution_drop.note: One and done. Don't over-explain. Don't list features. If they ask 'how does it work?' — that's buying interest. Answer briefly, then move to CTA. Don't get sucked into a product demo on the phone.

branches.label: Interested / 'that's cool' / asks how it works
We don't have budget for that right now
I'd need to run that by my partners

cta_meeting.label: ASK FOR THE MEETING
cta_meeting.say: Would you be open to taking a look — like fifteen minutes where I can show you what it actually catches? Totally low-key, no pitch deck. I'll just run it on a couple of your actual properties so you can see it in context. Not while I'm cold calling you out of the blue.
cta_meeting.note: You're selling the meeting, not the product. Make it sound easy and low-commitment. If they hesitate, add: 'Worst case you see what other PM companies in San Diego are doing with their turnover photos and you steal some ideas.'

branches.label: Need to loop in my partners first
Just send me an email first

booking.label: BOOK IT NOW
booking.say: Awesome. I've got next week pulled up — would Tuesday or Thursday work better for you? I can do morning or afternoon.
booking.note: Two choices, not an open question. Once they pick a day, narrow to a specific time. Get it locked before they reconsider. Have your calendar actually pulled up.

branches.label: Wants to check calendar / 'send me an invite'

booking_confirmed.label: MEETING BOOKED — WRAP UP
booking_confirmed.say: Perfect — I'll shoot you a calendar invite at erik.trogden@casago.com right now. Really appreciate you taking my call, Erik. Looking forward to it.
booking_confirmed.note: Send the calendar invite WHILE on the phone. Stop selling immediately. Don't add features, don't recap, don't oversell. Keep it short and warm. You won.

objection_no_budget.label: OBJECTION — NO BUDGET
objection_no_budget.say: Totally get it. Especially with everything going on right now — onboarding all the new properties, getting systems standardized — I'm sure every dollar's accounted for.
objection_no_budget.note: Agree first. Reference their specific situation to show empathy and understanding. Then split the objection to figure out if it's timing, money, or process.

budget_split.label: SPLIT — BUDGET
budget_split.say: Just so I know — is it that budget for this cycle is completely locked, or is it more that buying anything new right now would have to go through a bunch of hoops with Casago corporate or your partners?
budget_split.note: You're fishing for whether this is a local franchise budget constraint or a corporate/partner approval issue. If it's corporate, that's actually encouraging — Casago just signed deals with Breezeway and Wheelhouse at the network level, so they're actively buying ops tools.

branches.label: Would need corporate or partner approval

objection_not_interested.label: OBJECTION — NOT INTERESTED
objection_not_interested.say: I totally get it. Honestly, I should've assumed you'd be all set — otherwise you probably would've reached out to us.
objection_not_interested.note: Agree fully. The self-deprecating frame lowers their guard. Don't argue. Just pause and let them respond — most people will soften and give you a reason.

branches.label: They soften / give a reason why
Firm no / wants off the call

not_interested_split.label: SPLIT — NOT INTERESTED
not_interested_split.say: Just so nobody from my team bugs you on this again — is it that turnover quality isn't really a focus right now, or is it more that you've got something in place already that's handling it?
not_interested_split.note: If they say they have something → go to process/vendor objection. If they say it's not a focus → unusual for someone who just onboarded 150 homes and promises 75-point checklists. Don't challenge them on it — just pivot to test drive.

branches.label: We already have something / process works

objection_have_process.label: OBJECTION — HAVE A PROCESS
objection_have_process.say: That makes total sense — with a hundred fifty-plus homes and the 75-point checklists you guys run, you'd have to have something solid in place. Totally respect that.
objection_have_process.note: You just named their specific checklist standard from their own marketing. This shows real depth of research and catches their attention. Now you'll split to see if they're truly happy or just settled.

branches.label: Surprised you know that / opens up more
Confirms they're happy with current setup

vendor_split.label: SPLIT — CURRENT PROCESS
vendor_split.say: Is it that Property Care's catching everything you need and you're feeling fully covered, or is it more that adding anything to the workflow right now — especially mid-transition with all the new properties — would just be a headache?
vendor_split.note: Naming Property Care X by name shows you know their exact stack. Most operators will quietly admit the tool organizes tasks but doesn't actually 'catch' issues — it's a checklist, not an intelligence layer. That gap is exactly what RapidEye fills.

branches.label: Says they're fully covered and happy

objection_partner_decision.label: OBJECTION — NEED PARTNERS' INPUT
objection_partner_decision.say: Totally makes sense — you've got Dave and Bert to loop in on this stuff. Would it make more sense to set up fifteen minutes with all three of you, or would you rather take a look first yourself and then bring it to them if it's worth their time?
objection_partner_decision.note: You named both partners by name — this shows you're not randomly dialing from a list. Give Erik the choice: be the internal champion who screens first, or bring everyone to the table at once. Either path works.

branches.label: Let's get all three of us on a call
Let me look first, then I'll bring it up
Send me something I can share with them
Not the right time for any of us

test_drive_pitch.label: SELL THE TEST DRIVE
test_drive_pitch.say: Look, you're probably not buying anything right now, and I totally respect that. But when the dust settles from the Vacasa transition and you're looking at what's working and what's not — the people who move fastest are the ones who already know what's on their list. If nothing else, I could show you what a couple other PM companies in San Diego are doing with their turnover photos right now. Worst case you steal some ideas and we part as friends.
test_drive_pitch.note: This is your last real swing. You're offering value regardless of whether they buy. The 'steal some ideas' line drops the stakes to zero. If they still say no, exit gracefully — don't push further.

send_email.label: THEY WANT AN EMAIL
send_email.say: Totally fair. One quick question before I do — what would be most useful to include so it doesn't just sit in your inbox as another generic pitch? Like, is it more the Streamline integration side, or would you rather see what it actually catches on real properties?
send_email.note: Two goals: (1) tailor the email so it actually gets opened, (2) keep them engaged for 10 more seconds to build just a little more rapport. Whatever they say, use it to customize the follow-up.

branches.label: Tells you what they want to see

send_email_tailor.label: CONFIRM EMAIL + PLANT A TIME
send_email_tailor.say: Got it — I'll send that over to erik.trogden@casago.com today. And I'll throw a time suggestion in there for next week in case you want to see it live. Appreciate you hearing me out, Erik.
send_email_tailor.note: Send the email within 30 minutes. Subject line should reference this call specifically. Include a concrete time suggestion (e.g., 'Would Thursday at 10am PT work?'). Follow up in 3 business days if no reply. Add to your CRM with notes from this conversation.

referral_path.label: REFERRAL — FIND THE RIGHT PERSON
referral_path.say: Got it — so between you, Dave, and Bert, who typically owns the operations and inspection side of things day-to-day? I just want to make sure I'm putting something together that lands with the right person.
referral_path.note: Three co-owners means one probably leans more ops than the others. Dave Carter was quoted in the Vacasa expansion press — he might be more externally facing. Get a clear name and ask for a warm intro if possible.

branches.label: Gives a name — Dave or Bert

referral_get_name.label: LOCK IN THE REFERRAL
referral_get_name.say: Perfect. Would it be cool if I mentioned you pointed me their way? Even a quick one-line email from you would go a long way. What's the best way to reach them — same casago.com email?
referral_get_name.note: If he says Dave: dave.carter@casago.com. If Bert: bert.king@casago.com. Ask if Erik would shoot a quick intro email — even 'hey, take this guy's call' dramatically increases your chances. Main office is (760) 999-0171 if you need to call in.

gatekeeper_initial.label: GATEKEEPER — SLIDE BY
gatekeeper_initial.say: Hey — could you get me through to Erik? It's Sam.
gatekeeper_initial.note: First name only for both of you. Say it like you belong. Don't volunteer anything else unless asked. If they put you through, go right into the opener.

gatekeeper_context.label: GATEKEEPER — ADD CONTEXT
gatekeeper_context.say: Yeah, I work with a few other property managers in North County San Diego. Would you mind letting Erik know it's Sam Parks?
gatekeeper_context.note: Still not pitching. You're giving just enough context to sound credible and relevant without triggering the sales-call filter. End with a redirect question — you ask the questions, you control the conversation.

branches.label: He's not available / pushes back more

gatekeeper_social_proof.label: GATEKEEPER — LAST ATTEMPT
gatekeeper_social_proof.say: Totally understand. We help a couple other vacation rental management companies with their inspection workflows — would you mind just giving him a heads up that Sam Parks called? And is there a better time to catch him?
gatekeeper_social_proof.note: You're planting a seed and gathering timing intel. If they give you a callback window, write it down and use it. If they offer voicemail, take it — but don't rely on a callback. Plan to call again.

branches.label: Gives a better time / takes a message

graceful_exit.label: EXIT — DON'T BURN THE BRIDGE
graceful_exit.say: Totally understand. If anything changes on your end, I'm easy to find — Sam Parks, RapidEye. Appreciate your time.
graceful_exit.note: Stay warm. Don't sound defeated or passive-aggressive. Erik and his partners manage 150+ properties in a top San Diego market — you'll likely circle back in 60 days or encounter them at an industry event. Leave every door open. If talking to a gatekeeper, drop Erik's name and keep it professional.
